titleStmt.title: Local predictive context accelerates evidence accumulation during semantic priming: a drift-diffusion approach

analytic.title: Local predictive context accelerates evidence accumulation during semantic priming: a drift-diffusion approach

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Imagine reading a shopping list: words such as apple, banana, and pear immediately create a strong sense of coherence, forming a predictable semantic context so that when the word orange appears, it is readily anticipated. In contrast, when the list begins with only apple followed by orange, the prediction is weaker despite semantic closeness. To capture this effect experimentally, participants (n = 20) performed a lexical decision task on targets preceded by either one prime (short condition) or three semantically related primes (long condition). This design allowed us to examine how local semantic predictability accumulated across multiple primes. Our results showed that repeated exposure to semantically related primes substantially accelerated decision-making-an effect we attribute to faster evidence accumulation for semantically similar prime-target pairs, as quantified by a drift-diffusion model. Our results thus extend our understanding of language prediction to minimal contexts, demonstrating that top-down facilitation can emerge rapidly from just a few preceding items. This study advances our understanding of how prediction shapes language processing and demonstrates the relevance of hierarchical decision-making models in behavioral research.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Exploring how prediction and semantic processing work together is key to understanding how we make sense of language in daily communication (Kuperberg & Jaeger, 2016). During online processing, the human brain is able to effortlessly process semantic relations between the current word and its preceding words or sentence contexts (Hagoort et al., 2004;Meyer & Schvaneveldt, 1971; for a review, see Henson, 2003;Kutas & Federmeier, 2011). Classic theories argue that this remarkable feature stems from our ability to integrate semantic relationships between incoming words and their preceding contexts (e.g. memory-based by Kuperberg, 2007; spreading activation by Kutas & Federmeier, 2011). However, more recent theories posit that, beyond semantic relationships, humans also use predictive cues at various levels, such as world knowledge, syntactic/thematic structure, and statistical regularity, that actively guides semantic processing (Kuperberg & Jaeger, 2016). These ideas align with predictive coding frameworks (Bastos et al., 2012;Clark, 2013;Keller & Mrsic-Flogel, 2018), which propose that the brain actively generates probabilistic predictions about upcoming inputs and uses new information to update its internal models, thereby creating an efficient predictive machine for processing language under uncertainty. Importantly, to date, studies on the interaction between semantic processing and prediction have primarily examined the semantic processing of words embedded in a sentence or even longer discourse contexts (e.g., Brothers et al., 2015;Heilbron et al., 2021;van Berkum et al., 1999). Although the stimulation from these studies is rich in its ecological validity, the observed predictive effects often reflect a combination of influences from multiple linguistic and non-linguistic resources. In contrast, few studies have also revealed how prediction -without any linguistic context -guides semantic processing during online processing. For example, in an event-related potential (ERP) study, Lau and colleagues (2013) manipulated the proportion of semantically associated prime-target pairs in a semantic category probe task and divided the experiment into two blocks with different proportions of related word pairs. Their findings revealed the significant role of predictability in modulating the N400 effect and suggested that predictions about upcoming stimuli could influence semantic processing at both early and late stages (Lau et al., 2013). This setup provided a framework for analyzing how participants adjusted their semantic predictions following the changing frequency of semantically related pairs. A follow-up modeling analysis by Delaney-Busch and colleagues (2019) further suggested that semantic prediction during language processing is subject to Bayesian principles, as derived from the statistical structure of the broader environment (but see Nieuwland (2021) for an alternative explanation). The studies above elegantly show that semantic processing can be guided by the statistical structure of the broader environment by leveraging only a minimal context (as in semantic priming). However, in addition to its adaptability to global environmental statistics, semantic priming may also be subject to constraints from context building at local levels. Following Delaney-Busch et al. (2019) and Lau et al. (2013), we extend the investigation of prediction in semantic processing to the local semantic context rather than a global context.

Imagine reading a shopping list. Seeing the words apple, banana, and pear together immediately creates a sense of coherence: they belong to the same category -fruits. Then, by the time you encounter the next item in the list orange, it feels seamlessly integrated into the context. Now, consider a different situation where the list begins with just apple, and then you encounter orange. While still semantically related, the context is less robust, and the sense of prediction is weaker. Translating into an experimental set up, these two scenariosone with a single prime (short condition) and one with multiple related primes (long condition) -illustrate an interesting difference regarding how semantic processing unfolds in response to varying amounts of local contextual buildup. In the short prime condition, semantic priming reflects an immediate process. The prime activates related concepts, facilitating the recognition of the target. In contrast, with gradual scaffolding of semantically similar items, the long prime condition provides a more dynamic and coherent context, allowing the local statistical regularities of these words to guide the immediate semantic process. Thus, in both conditions, although the semantic relationships between the targets and their preceding contexts are identical, the semantic processing at the target words could be potentially different. Indeed, in a recent study by 3/12/25 4:37:00 PM, the authors investigated the role of probabilistic semantic representations in eliciting the N400 ERP using a semantic oddball-like roving paradigm. Importantly, with additional manipulation of the transition probability between categories they assessed how the brain adapted its predictions based on the statistical structure of the input. Although Lindborg et al. (2023) did not compare the ERPs within repetition conditions, they fit a Bayesian sequential learner model to derive semantic surprise and showed that the N400 amplitude is best explained by this model where the amount of within-category repetition is taken into consideration. This is the first evidence suggesting that even in a minimal context semantic processing can be guided by differential levels of local contextual buildup.

Most studies to date have used N400 as a proxy for semantic processing (see a review by Kutas & Federmeier, 2011), but surprisingly, empirical evidence from behavioral measures is scarce. While N400 provides a window into the brain's implicit semantic processing mechanisms, behavioral data, on the other hands, offers a complementary perspective by capturing how these processes translate into overt responses. More importantly, beyond the direct behavioral outcome measures, such as reaction times and accuracy, by applying the Drift Diffusion Model (DDM) to behavioral data, we can gain insights into the underlying cognitive mechanisms (Ratcliff et al., 2004(Ratcliff et al., , 2016. This approach allows us to disentangle the contributions of semantic processing and local contextual prediction to decision-making processes, distinguishing between changes in processing efficiency (e.g., drift rate) and adjustments in decision-making strategies (e.g., boundary separation), thus providing a richer understanding of how semantic processing operates in real-world tasks where both automatic priming and context-driven facilitation play a role (Todorova et al., 2020;Yoon et al., 2021).

We therefore set up the current behavioral study, levering the DDM approach, to offer a new perspective on how semantic processing is influenced by differential levels of predictability during local context buildup. Building on but extending a conventional semantic priming condition (standard prime-target combination, short condition), we set up a long condition where expectation of a within-category target is strengthened, thereby amplifying the semantic priming effect. This effect will be evaluated via both conventional behavioral and modern modeling (DDM) approaches, thus providing a clearer understanding of how predictive mechanisms operate independently and in conjunction with semantic processing and revealing new aspects of the language processing dynamics.

div.head: Participants
div.p: We collected data from 20 healthy, right-handed, native German speakers aged 18 to 35 years, with normal or corrected-to-normal vision and no reported language or mental disorders (7 males, MeanAge = 24.6, SDAge = 3.25). We determined the number of participants established in previous studies that implemented DDM analysis in a semantic priming task using a lexical decision task (LDT) (Perea et al., 2016;Ratcliff et al., 2004;Wagenmakers et al., 2008), ensuring alignment with the established sample sizes in similar studies. Before the start of the experiment, the participants were assessed with Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (EHI; Oldfield, 1971). All participants provided written consent to take part in the study, which was approved by the ethics commission of the University Hospital of Giessen and Marburg. Participants were recruited via email within Phillips University Marburg and were paid 25 euros for their participation.

div.head: Stimuli
div.p: We selected 20 categories of objects, each represented by four examples such that they were (1) close in frequency and (2) highly semantically similar. Frequency was measured using frequency values from the SUBTLEX-DE database (Brysbaert et al., 2011), and semantic similarity by vector differences of word embeddings from the fast-text model for German (Grave et al., 2018). The examples of each category were carefully chosen to be close, both in frequency and vector difference values. The stimuli list was organized such that each category's example could be reused as an outside-category target in prime sequences with words from the other category. For example, as dog from the category animals can be used as an outside-category target after apple, an example from the category fruits. The stimulus list by category is presented in Supplementary Table S1.

div.head: Design
div.p: For the experiment, we used the stimuli list to create within-and outside-category prime-target sequences. Building on a conventional semantic priming paradigm, besides the standard prime-target pair (short condition), we introduce a long condition that includes three primes belonging to the same category (e.g. Figure 1). In this condition, as participants encountered successive words from the same category, their expectation that the next word would belong to the same category strengthened. Thus, by manipulating the shared semantic information between stimuli in this experimental design, we expect that this enhanced expectation modulates the conventional semantic priming effect, reflected by reaction time (RT) and accuracy. . Schematic overview of the short (A) and long (B) trial conditions. Each trial started with a fixation cross (500ms), followed by two words in the short condition (A) and four words in the long condition (B). Each word was presented for 300ms with an inter-stimulus interval of 200ms. At the end of the trial, participants were asked to evaluate whether the previous word was real by pressing a key (counterbalanced across them) corresponding to yes (Y) or no (N) (2s) queued by a question mark. The trials were separated by a 1000 ± 500ms interval (ITI).

Two experimental lists were created, each with 960 trials, equally divided between the long and short conditions (see Supplementary Materials 1 for a detailed description of the randomization procedure). One-way ANOVA showed no significant difference in the target word length (in letters) between the lists (F(1) = 0, p =.99) and condition (F(1) = 0.2, p =.65). There was also no significant difference in the target frequency between the lists (F(1) = 0.95, p =.33) and condition (F(1) = 0.56, p =.45).

div.head: Procedure
div.p: The experiment was performed on a computer in a university laboratory setting. Before the start of the experiment, the participants completed a demographic questionnaire and the EHI, which lasted five minutes. The experiment was presented on a 24.1 inch monitor with PsychoPy (Peirce et al., 2019) on a Windows operating system. To respond to the stimuli, participants used a Super Nintendo Entertainment System controller.

During the task, participants saw words preceded by fixation and were instructed to respond to a question mark cue, judging whether the last word was a real or pseudoword. Pseudowords were created by changing one letter in a real word from the stimuli list, producing phonetically plausible but meaningless German words. Each pseudoword was reviewed by two native German speakers. Participants were unaware of whether the current word sequence was short or long. The total duration of the experiment was approximately 1 h 10 min. Before the start of testing, participants completed training consisting of 12 trials, in which they were provided feedback after each trial. Feedback was not present during testing.

div.head: Data Preprocessing
div.p: RT outliers were removed based on a 100ms threshold. The current cohort's high yet accurate speeded responses resulted in a lower threshold than in previous studies (e.g. Perea et al., 2016;Ratcliff et al., 2004;Wagenmakers et al., 2008), suggesting their proficiency in behavioral studies. A total of 3.9% of the data were excluded. No trials were removed due to accuracy, as all participants met the 80% threshold (M = 0.95, SD = 0.32). For the DDM analysis, incorrect responses were changed to -1 to fit the framework requirements (accuracy coding).

div.head: Data Analysis
div.p: Following previous literature (e.g. Chakroun et al., 2023;Colwell et al., 2024;Laquitaine et al., 2024;Pagnier et al., 2024), we integrated both statistical and computational modeling approaches using traditional statistical methods, such as linear mixed-effects regression (LMER; Bates et al., 2015) along with DDM (Wiecki et al., 2013). This combination of statistical analysis and computational modeling offers a comprehensive framework for interpreting both the observable and underlying aspects of the data, thereby improving the robustness and clarity of our findings.

To treat prime-target relationships, we used a semantic similarity measure. Unlike binary or categorical condition labels (e.g., related vs. unrelated), continuous measures offer a more nuanced understanding of meaning by detecting subtle variations (Broderick et al., 2018). This approach provides a more sensitive index of semantic processing and better predicts cognitive processes, making it a valuable tool for studying language comprehension (Günther et al., 2016). For example, a binary measure would treat both apple and orange as equally related to fruit as apple and tomato, simply categorizing them as either related or unrelated. However, a continuous measure of semantic similarity can capture a more subtle distinction that apple and orange share a closer meaning than apple and tomato. This distinction is crucial for understanding how language is processed, as it reflects varying degrees of similarity between concepts in natural language.

In contrast to studies that used pseudowords as fillers, we analyzed the data for both real and pseudowords, as a broader range of items provides a more comprehensive assessment of participant performance, offering a clearer understanding of the cognitive mechanisms involved in language comprehension beyond simply recognizing known words (Strauß et al., 2022).

div.head: LMER
div.p: RTs and accuracy from LDT were first analyzed using an LMER model (lmer function from the lme4 package in R (Bates et al., 2015)). We implemented separate LMER models for real and pseudowords that included fixed effects for condition and semantic similarity to support a more detailed analysis of their interaction. All models included a random subject effect.

div.head: DDM
div.p: DDM is a framework well suited to characterize the underlying decision processes reflected in RT and accuracy data, particularly when tasks involve accumulating evidence towards a decision boundary(e.g. Berger et al., 2022;Tillman et al., 2017;Wagenmakers et al., 2008). For DDM model fitting and analysis, we used a hierarchical, Bayesian DDM approach as implemented in the HSSM 0.2.2 package (Fengler et al., in prep.) (Wiecki et al., 2013). The choice of hierarchical models over non-hierarchical once was influenced by their greater robustness, particularly with fewer observations per subject (Ratcliff & Childers, 2015).

A classic Wiener four-parameter DDM (Ratcliff, 1978) was implemented in our analysis. This DDM estimates four key parameters: non-decision time (denoted as t), which captures processes unrelated to decision-making; drift rate (v), which represents the speed and direction of evidence accumulation towards a decision; boundary separation (a), which determines the amount of information needed to make a choice; and starting point (z), which indicates the initial position of evidence accumulation in relation to the decision criteria (Ratcliff et al., 2004). Together, these parameters capture the speed-accuracy trade-off of the decision, promoting a more nuanced understanding of how predictions influence the decisionmaking process. This level of insight helps uncover the mechanisms by which semantic relationships impact prediction, offering a clearer picture of the cognitive dynamics at play in priming tasks. Inter-trial variability parameters were not included, as our LDT involves a stable forced-choice decision with minimal response bias, and thus does not require added model complexity. The starting point parameter was fixed due to the use of accuracy coding.

As established in previous research, we set the primary parameter influenced by participants' behavior to be the drift rate (Ratcliff et al., 2004), which reflects the speed of evidence accumulation during word recognition (the extent to which a stimulus is perceived as word-like). High drift rate suggests that information is gathered rapidly and decisively, resulting in quicker and more accurate responses. In contrast, low drift rate indicates slower and less clear accumulation of information, leading to delayed and potentially less accurate decisions. Apart from the drift rate, the decision boundary and non-decision time parameters were fixed.

To investigate whether the effect of semantic similarity between the target and prime on the DDM parameters varied depending on the experimental conditions, we first split the data into trials with real or pseudoword targets and then added an interaction term between semantic similarity and condition (long vs. short). With this approach, we expected to observe a pronounced impact of prediction effects on the classic priming effect (semantic similarity), specifically in the long condition, compared to a baseline established in the short condition, and that this effect would be reflected by altered effect of evidence accumulation (v) as a function of semantic similarity.

We used an MCMC sampling algorithm for the parameter estimation. generating 5,000 samples. This process initially involved the production of 2,500 burn-in samples, which were then discarded to negate any potential influence of preliminary exploratory values prior to convergence. Model convergence was evaluated through the Gelman-Rubin statistic (all rhats < 1.01). Since hierarchical DDM is essentially a Bayesian approach, the posterior distributions of the model parameters were directly compared to zero according to the Bayesian tradition to infer statistical significance. For drift rate, we report posterior means and 97% confidence intervals (<0.03 overlap of distribution indicating statistical significance) to characterize group-level decision processes.

div.head: LMER
div.p: We report the interaction-only LMER and DDM analyses, providing a clear basis for comparing the effects across both methods. Subsequent models included a random intercept for subjects and were estimated via the restricted maximum likelihood (see Supplementary Materials 2 for the full models' formula). As a result of the non-normal distribution of models' residuals, a Box-Cox transformation was applied to the RT data: RT values were multiplied by the estimated lambda to correct for skewness and improve the normality of the residuals.

The model for real words accounted for 36% of the variance in RT, with fixed effects explaining 13%. The interaction effects of semantic similarity and condition are summarized in Supplementary Table S3. The interaction between semantic similarity and long condition had a negative effect (p < .001), indicating that long condition, compared to short condition, facilitated quicker responses to targets similar to primes. In contrast, the interaction between semantic similarity and short condition had a positive effect (p < .001), demonstrating longer RTs when prime-target pairs were more similar.

Next, LMER was fit to predict accuracy using the same fixed and random effects. The model had very weak explanatory power (conditional R² < 0.01), with fixed effects accounting for less than 1% of the variance. Supplementary Table S4 shows the interaction effects. The analysis of real word data revealed a positive effect of semantic similarity interacting with long condition (p < .001), suggesting that long condition positively influenced accuracy when the target and prime were semantically related. Together with the findings from the RT model, it shows that participants performed in LDT better after seeing three primes in the long condition as opposed to one in the short condition.

The same models predicting RT and accuracy were built for the pseudowords data. Supplementary Table S5 summarizes the interaction effects. The model predicting RT accounted for 26% of the variance, whereas the fixed effects accounted for 3%. The model demonstrated a negative effect of the interaction between semantic similarity and long condition (p < .001) and a positive effect of the interaction between semantic similarity and short condition (p < .001), consistent with the findings from the real words model. Subsequently, LMER was fit to predict the accuracy for pseudowords. The explanatory power of the model was weak (conditional R² = 0.03), with fixed effects accounting for less than 1% of the variance. The interaction effects can be found in Supplementary Table S6. The model showed a negative effect of the interaction between similarity and short condition (p = .003), reflecting lower accuracy in the short condition and aligning with the results of the real words model.

To improve the interpretability of the semantic similarity effect, for illustration, we performed a median split by dividing the data into high-and low-similarity groups. This allowed us to separate the data into two distinct groups, which were then plotted by condition, showing their relationship with the RT and accuracy in Figure 2. Descriptive statistics are available in Supplementary Table S7. Overall, the analysis of two LMER models for real words data demonstrated that long condition boosted LDT performance, especially for semantically similar target and primes, thus highlighting the effect of prime quantity on task proficiency. Observed effects for the pseudowords data corresponded to the results from the real words, emphasizing the universality of the mechanism regardless of the target lexicality. Altogether, these results demonstrate the importance of prime exposure on the task performance that applies to both real and pseudowords.

div.head: DDM
div.p: Given our primary research question on how prediction influences the effect of semantic similarity on participants' LDT behavior, we focused on an interaction-only model that looks at how the effect of semantic similarity differs between conditions. Notably, by hypothesis, we focused our analysis on models where only drift rate varies. However, we also conducted a comprehensive model comparison for all theoretically possible models. A comprehensive summary of the models is reported in Supplement Materials 4.

The model applied to real words with only drift rate variation demonstrated a significant negative effect in the short condition on drift rate (p = 0, 97% HDI [-0.98, -0.61], Figure 3, left), showing that participants accumulated evidence slower for prime-target pairs with higher semantic similarity when there was only one prime. Long condition, in contrast, had a significant positive effect (p = 0, 97% HDI [1.03, 1.36]), meaning that participants processed information more quickly for targets with higher semantic similarity when there were three primes. This suggests that the number of primes and their semantic similarity with the target impacted how efficiently participants processed information and made choices in the LDT.

The analysis of pseudoword data revealed effects on drift rate similar to those observed in real words, specifically, a negative effect of short condition (p = 0, 97% HDI [-0.98, -0.61], Figure 3, right), and a positive effect of long condition (p = 0, 97% HDI [1.03, 1.36]). Despite the pattern similarity to real words, the posterior density distributions in pseudowords were generally more spread out than those for real words. The consistent findings for real and pseudowords indicate that the cognitive mechanisms of lexical decisionmaking were stable across different types of linguistic input. Overall, the analysis of the DDM parameters for both real and pseudowords revealed that the observed positive drift rate effect reflected the impact of semantic similarity on decision-making in the long condition, indicating that participants accumulated evidence faster when presented three primes. In contrast, negative drift rate effect on semantic similarity in the short condition demonstrated that participants accumulated evidence more slowly with limited prime exposure. Notably, these effects remained stable for both types of targets, indicating that participants likely employed similar strategies when evaluating both real and pseudowords.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The goal of this study was to examine how prediction shapes semantic priming by manipulating local context buildup. As observed from both the conventional behavioral and modern modeling results, our key findings demonstrated that the effect of semantic similarity on drift rate clearly differed for long vs. short conditions. This effect is comparable between real and pseudowords; it is also in line with the data pattern as observed from the RT. In the DDM framework, drift rate represents evidence accumulation, that is, collecting cues over time that support one decision over another. The results of the study showed that prediction enhanced the semantic priming effect by accelerating the speed and efficiency of evidence accumulation for targets that were semantically more similar to primes. In other words, despite identical prime-target semantic relationships, with repeated exposure to semantically related primes participants were able to make quicker and more confident decisions. Extending previous studies that examined neural correlates of semantic processing and found a facilitative effect of prediction (Lau et al., 2013;Lindborg et al., 2023), our findings provide the first behavioral evidence demonstrating similar predictive mechanisms in language processing.

For instance, similar to Lau and colleagues (2013), who found an increased N400 priming effect in a block with a high proportion of related prime-target pairs that reflected enhanced predictive processing, our results revealed faster evidence accumulation (and shorter RTs) for semantically similar targets only in the long condition. Notably, the blocklevel manipulations from Lau and colleagues (2013) might reflect broader strategic effects in the sense that participants might have adopted a general expectancy that most pairs will be related, leading to top-down biases. In contrast, here, by using a more local manipulation, we demonstrate that the brain is able to dynamically update its semantic predictions from one prime to the next in an online fashion. These observations also echo the N400 findings of Lindborg et al. (2023), but from a behavioral perspective. Given that predictive coding theories would suggest automatic updating in response to new evidence, our results corroborate previous findings and provide direct evidence of how this prediction evolves in a word-by-word manner.

It is surprising that, in contrast to many classic semantic priming studies, we did not observe a priming effect in the short condition in either the conventional or the DDM analysis. In contrast, the slower drift rate for semantically more similar targets, as observed in our short condition, highlighted how limited exposure to semantically related primes impeded the evidence accumulation process compared with the long condition. The lack of a semantic priming effect typically reported in a classical paradigm has been attributed to an insufficient degree of relatedness to elicit a priming response (Moss et al., 1995) or the influence of strategic priming (Shelton & Martin, 1992). Besides, McRae & Boisvert (1998) showed that the priming effect could be modulated by shorter stimulus onset asynchrony for less-related word pairs. Clearly, these accounts do not sufficiently explain our obseserved effects here. Interestingly, Küper & Heil (2009) observed a semantic priming effect only in EEG measures but not in behavioral RTs, suggesting that neural facilitation may occur even in the absence of behavioral effects. This finding points to the value of incorporating EEG methods in future studies, which could yield more insight into the neurological processes underlying the absence of the priming effect observed in the short condition.

Notably, by reanalyzing the data from Lau et al. (2013), Nieuwland (2021) reported that forward association strength did not appear to have much of an effect in roughly the first 50 trials, suggesting the possibility that prediction effects could have varied among trials throughout the task. Motivated by these findings, we might then suspect that the surprising semantic similarity effect in the short condition may derive from a gradual interference effect -they may gradually appear to be less and less predictive when more predictive long condition trials were presented throughout the experiment. We thus examined whether trial progression influenced task progression by running a by-block analysis using DDM, dividing all trials into eight blocks of 60 trials each. This analysis showed that the semantic similarity effect of both the long and short conditions was present from the very first block for real word targets. These findings thus rule out the possibility that our short condition effect emerged only after extensive trial-by-trial adaptation, indicating that, instead, participants rapidly engaged in predictive processing for both conditions. (see Supplementary Materials 5 for the DDM report).

It is also worth noting that across both real and pseudoword targets, we observed a consistent data pattern. This suggests that participants employed similar evaluative strategies regardless of lexical status. Prior literature has shown that, in a lexical decision task, real and pseudowords may be processed differently: compared to real words, pseudowords processing is affected by both phonotactic probability and neighborhood density. However, the pattern from our analysis suggest that, despite differences, even pseudowords can nevertheless engage semantic memory mechanisms as long as they share sufficient orthographic cues (Gatti et al., 2023), and this activated semantic representation can be similarly facilitated by prediction. This converging evidence highlights the idea that prediction might function at a more generalized level that goes beyond lexical representations.

Considering both the DDM and LMER analyses, our findings provide a more comprehensive understanding of how local semantic predictability influences language processing. While the LMER models indicated that participants were generally slower and less accurate in the short condition compared to the long condition, DDM offered additional clarity by explaining the underlying cognitive mechanisms. Specifically, the slower drift rate in the short condition suggested that participants accumulated evidence more slowly and with less certainty when only one prime was presented. This slower evidence accumulation likely contributed to the longer RTs and decreased accuracy observed in the LMER models, as participants required more time to reach the decision threshold and were more likely to make errors due to weaker evidence. Thus, while LMER revealed observable behavior, DDM provided insight into the cognitive processes driving this behavior.

The outcomes of the LMER and DDM analyses showed substantial similarity: as LMER showed more rapid and accurate processing of the targets in the long condition, DDM captured faster evidence accumulation in the long condition and slower drift rate in the short condition. Compared to conventional RT and accuracy data analysis, DDM offers a more nuanced explanation by modeling the speed-accuracy trade off. This approach helps determine whether changes in RT reflect actual processing efficiency or more conservative decision criteria, providing deeper insights into how participants reached their decision (Ratcliff et al., 2016). As demonstrated in prior literature, DDM corrects the oversimplification of the classical analysis approach and prevents the misinterpretation of RT data (Ratcliff et al., 2010).

While previous DDM studies typically focused on how word frequency or lexicality affects decision-making during LDT (e.g. Berger et al., 2022;Perea et al., 2016;Wagenmakers et al., 2008;Yang et al., 2022), few studies also investigated semantic priming with DDM. For example, Gomez and colleagues (2013) also observed a drift rate effect related to semantic processing in an unmasked priming task, demonstrating the sensitivity of drift rate to semantic relatedness. Here, by applying DDM to a priming paradigm tailored for predictive coding, we again observed a drift rate effect for semantic priming, corroborating previous literature. This convergence suggests that evidence accumulation dynamics play a consistent role in semantic processing across different priming designs. Moreover, we were able to attribute the local context-driven predictive facilitation in our long prime condition to accelerated evidence accumulation rather than shortened decision boundary. This novel insight clarifies how prediction interacts with semantic processing during lexical decisionmaking. By pinpointing the precise mechanism of predictive facilitation here, our findings potentially extend the theoretical landscape for studying prediction in language. Future research could apply DDM to alternative experimental paradigms, such as a picture-word verification task (Ford et al., 2001), or introduce an instruction to yield a speed-accuracy trade-off (Fitts, 1966). Moreover, by applying a neurally informed DDM approach (Ratcliff et al., 2016), we could explore how neural correlates of language processing (e.g., the N400) differentially underlie behavioral decision-making under predictive influence. Finally, as DDM is particularly sensitive to individual differences (White et al., 2016), its applicability extends to research involving clinical populations, allowing for the dissociation of dysfunctional cognitive processes (Forstmann et al., 2016). For example, prior research has indicated that reduced neural semantic priming in schizophrenia can be explained by impairments in probabilistic prediction (Sharpe et al., 2020). Then the application of DDM may attribute this impaired predictive language processing in schizophrenia to a specific mechanism, be it slowed drift rate, or altered boundary separation, or potentially both. In sum, leveraging DDM within a predictive-coding framework opens new avenues, both in typical cognition and disorders characterized by impaired predictive mechanisms.

Summing up, our study provides compelling evidence that prediction enhances semantic priming by accelerating evidence accumulation, with its effects varying based on the extent of the local context buildup. Drawing on the DDM analysis, this study offers a critical contribution to our understanding of the role of prediction in language comprehension, addressing the gap in research that has largely overlooked behavioral data. We introduce a novel experimental paradigm that explores the effect of predictive processing on language comprehension within a minimal predictability context, filling a gap in prior studies that have focused on broader contexts. Ultimately, this study contributes to a more nuanced understanding of how prediction shapes language processing, offering a new experimental approach and demonstrating the relevance of DDM application in behavioral research. To construct the experimental list, we manipulated the order of words within the same category, ensuring that each word appeared at every position across all conditions. This approach dictated the number of trials following a permutation without repetition, resulting in 24 unique sequences, where each of the four words occurred exactly once in each of the four slots for each target type. To minimize the number of trials and participants' fatigue, we created two experimental lists. In the first experimental list, the first half of the stimuli was presented in the long condition (480 trials), whereas the second half was presented in the short condition (480 trials). Conversely, in the second experimental list, the order was reversed ( Figure S1 provides a schematic overview). This design resulted in 960 trials in the experimental session. All trials in each of the experimental lists were pseudo-randomized, so there were no sequences longer than three trials of the same condition (short/long) and category. Figure S1. Distribution of stimuli among experimental lists.

div.head: Supplementary Materials 2
div.p: Models' formulas LMER Predicting Reaction Time Similarity:Condition lmer(bc_rt ~ semantic_similarity:condition + (1|subj_idx), data=data_real_word) Note. A separate dataset data_pseudoword was used for pseudowords in all instances where the variable data_real_word appears in the model formula. HSSM( data= data_real_word, model="ddm", include=[ { "name": "v", "formula": "v ~ 1 + semantic_similarity:condition", "link": "identity", } ], ) Note. A separate dataset data_pseudoword was used for pseudowords in all instances where the variable data_real_word appears in the model formula. Detailed Two-Sample Dependent T-Test Results For the RT of real word targets, the t-test showed slower responses in the short condition for both high and low semantic similarity targets. For prime-target pairs with high semantic similarity, RT in the short condition (M = 635 ms, SD = 120 ms) was significantly slower than that in the long condition (M = 474 ms, SD = 119 ms, t(19) = 8.51, p < .001). Similarly, when the prime and target shared a low degree of semantic similarity, RT in the short condition (M = 635 ms, SD = 132 ms) was significantly slower than that in the long condition (M = 489 ms, SD = 138 ms), t(19) = 6.97, p < .001. Furthermore, the median split had a marginally significant effect on RT in the long condition, with targets more semantically similar to primes showing faster responses (M = 474 ms, SD = 119 ms) compared to less semantically similar targets (M = 489 ms, SD = 138 ms, t(19) = -2.37, p = .029). The effects on accuracy mirrored those observed for RT, with accuracy being higher for prime-target pairs with lower semantic similarity in the long condition (M = .96, SD = .03) than in the short condition (M = .91, SD = .04, t(19) = -5.28, p < .001). On top of that, there was an effect of the median split in the short condition, where targets more similar to the primes had higher accuracy (M = .94, SD = .06) than targets less similar to the primes (M = .91, SD =.04, t(19) = 3.4, p = .003).

div.head: Predicting Accuracy Similarity:Condition lmer(response ~ semantic_similarity:condition + (1|subj_idx), data=data_real_word
Supplementary Materials 3
div.p: Regarding the pseudoword target data, when prime-target pairs exhibited high semantic similarity (here, similarity denotes the connection between the prime and the original real word from which the pseudoword was derived), the RT in the short condition (M = 460 ms, SD = 103 ms) was notably slower than in the long condition (M = 382 ms, SD = 112 ms, t(19) = 5.38, p < .001). Likewise, for prime-target pairs with low semantic similarity, the RT in the short condition (M = 449 ms, SD = 106 ms) was significantly slower compared to the long condition (M = 460 ms, SD = 107 ms), t(19) = 5.92, p < .001. The accuracy findings paralleled those observed for RT, with higher accuracy for prime-target pairs of lower semantic similarity in the long condition (M = .97, SD = .05) compared to the short condition (M = .92, SD = .08, t(19) = -4.31, p < .001).

div.head: Supplementary Materials 4 Model Comparison
div.p: All Similarity:Condition models with varying parameters were compared using a null model without any parameters as a reference. The ELPD scores indicated that the best model was that with varying drift rate (v) and boundary separation (a). Boundary separation represents the decision threshold at which sufficient information is accumulated to classify a stimulus as a real or pseudoword . This parameter captures the trade-off between speed and accuracy: wider boundary separation leads to slower but more accurate responses, as it requires more information before a decision is made. Conversely, narrower boundary separation results in faster but less accurate responses due to the reduced information required for a decision. The inclusion of boundary separation and drift rate in the best-fitting model indicated that participants dynamically adjusted both their processing efficiency and decision-making strategy in response to the task demands ( Supplementary Tables 13 and 15).

Nevertheless, in the main text we report the classical drift rate variation-only DDM results due to their interpretability and well-established framework in the decision-making literature. This model allows us to draw meaningful comparisons with existing research and provides a stable foundation for understanding the cognitive mechanisms at play in our study. We encourage future research to further investigate the model including both varying drift rate and separation boundary to explore its implications in greater depth. Model names are structured such that the characters following the underscore indicate the parameters allowed to vary. The model ending with 0 represents a model with no free parameters. This convention applies to all subsequent model comparison tables. In accordance with the model comparison results for real words, analyses for pseudowords were limited to the comparison of v (as a canonically suitable model for a lexical decision task ) and va (as the best model for real words data) models.

figure.head: Figure 1
figure.figDesc: Figure 1. Schematic overview of the short (A) and long (B) trial conditions. Each trial started with a fixation cross (500ms), followed by two words in the short condition (A) and four words in the long condition (B). Each word was presented for 300ms with an inter-stimulus interval of 200ms. At the end of the trial, participants were asked to evaluate whether the previous word was real by pressing a key (counterbalanced across them) corresponding to yes (Y) or no (N) (2s) queued by a question mark. The trials were separated by a 1000 ± 500ms interval (ITI).

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: Comparison of response time (RT) and accuracy (ACC) for high-and low-similarity groups based on the median split in short and long conditions for real (left) and pseudowords (right). Each point represents the average value of interest per participant for each median split group and condition. Asterisks indicate significant effects (*p < .05, **p < .01, ***p < .001) in a two-sample dependent t-test (seeSupplementary Materials 3for additional details).

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Effects of similarity and condition interaction on drift rate for real and pseudowords represented by posterior densities, with horizontal lines below each distribution representing 97% HDIs.

that uses advanced Bayesian methods in Python to efficiently model and analyze data through rapid Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling. Unlike analytical DDMs, Bayesian models estimate the full posterior distribution of each parameter, offering a richer representation of uncertainty
